definition[0]: time that you spend working in your job in addition to your normal working hours
example[1]: They’re working overtime to get the job finished.
example[2]: He’s been doing a lot of overtime recently.
example[3]: Many employees work countless hours of unpaid overtime.
example[4]: Many of our offices will be working on overtime until the end of the year.
definition[1]: the money that you are paid for working more hours than usual
example[5]: He earns £450 a week, including overtime.
definition[2]: a period of time added to the end of a sports game to give one of the two teams a chance to win
example[6]: Steve Smith scored all nine of the Hawks’ points in overtime.
example[7]: He's been working a lot of overtime.
example[8]: I did three hours overtime yesterday.
example[9]: To earn enough money, he puts in a lot of overtime.
example[10]: Many teachers do a lot of unpaid overtime.
example[11]: They offered us a bonus and unlimited overtime.
example[12]: The salary figure does not include overtime pay.
example[13]: If Joe worked 100 hours overtime at time and a half, his overtime payments would be $15,662.
example[14]: Generous overtime rates are paid for late-night and weekend work.
example[15]: Is there any limit on your ability to work overtime?
example[16]: Staff at the bank will begin an overtime ban (=refuse to work overtime) tomorrow in a protest over pay.
example[17]: Police officers who do this extra work are paid overtime.
example[18]: They need paid holidays and vacations, as well as overtime pay for extra hours.
definition[3]: time that a factory, office etc is operating in addition to its normal hours
example[19]: The plant has worked overtime in some recent weeks because those models are selling well.
